Award.AwardTitle: New Methods for Molding Models to Specific Cases to Enhance Policy Predictions

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
General Audience Summary

This project aims to enhance policy effectiveness by focusing on ways to improve models that are used to estimate whether a social policy will achieve its intended outcomes when implemented in the setting at hand, in the way it would be implemented in that setting. The project will provide a systematic, theoretically grounded approach for deciding what kinds of evidence are good to collect, and for deciding how to put the evidence together to ascertain what it shows about the chances of success. Policy outcomes will always be uncertain, often greatly so. This project has promise to substantially improve predicting outcomes in individual cases by providing methods for molding models to the cases at hand. The results of this research will have potential to improve policy effectiveness and to suggest new kinds of scientific studies to support policy prediction; they will be disseminated across a number of policy domains.

Technical Summary

This project is an investigation of the kinds of evidence, both local and scientific, that can be used to build full enough models to make reasonable, albeit uncertain, policy predictions. The methodology is primarily analytic, and it builds on studies in the history, philosophy, and sociology of science on evidence, objectivity, and causal modeling. It also builds on the PI's recent work on evidencing singular causal claims and on causal mechanisms. The project involves in-depth study of cases in the natural and the social sciences, engineering, and the law of successful single-case prediction and post-hoc evaluation in complicated systems. It will develop categories of evidence, and it will refine and test the proposed model structure to see how well it fits successful cases. The project should contribute to the philosophical understanding of singular causation, currently a big topic in philosophy. It should advance understanding of causal modeling, in principle and in practice, especially in the social sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project aimed to develop ways to use causal models to produce better predictions about what will happen when we act – as in setting and implementing new social policies. In particular, it was concerned with what evidence we can have about the reliability of those predictions. For prediction, a very particular form of causal model is needed: a SCEM – a situation-specific causal equations model – meant to encode what the actual causal possibilities are in the situation at hand. A perfectly filled-in SCEM shows just what will happen if we do what we plan. This is naturally impossible to achieve. But various different kinds of evidence can help fill in bits of the SCEM; seeing what’s missing shows just what we are betting on in proceeding.

The principal impact should be  evidence-based social policy, where, it is argued, a good randomized controlled trial shows that the policy worked in the study setting. The same reult can then be expected to occur in settings represented by the same/similar enough SCEMs. So: When will that be the case? To answer, we can naturally gather new evidence in the new setting to fill in the SCEM there.

Project research showed another route. What causal relations are possible in a given social setting depends on the underlying social/political/cultural/economic/physical structures that obtain there. (Think: pressing the lever on a toaster produces a different outcome than pressing the lever on a toilet – and that’s due to differences between their underlying structures.) So, if we understand the social/etc. structure, we can figure out what SCEM is appropriate. Part of the research established a way to understand better this relation between the underlying structure of a setting and the corresponding SCEM.

Next, recognizing that similarity of underlying structure is what matters for exporting successful predictions from one setting to another led to a significant re-envisaging of the landscape in evidence-based policy: a distinction between intervention-centered and context-centered approaches. The intervention-centered focus on intervention-outcome pairs, establishing with high certainty that the intervention/policy produced the outcome ‘somewhere’. They suffer because they look chiefly at evidence for simple intervention-output relations and do not consider evidence available given a full SCEM and because they have no natural methodology for evaluating when an intervention-output relation that holds in one setting will hold in another.

The context-centered look for the kind of situation-specific information relevant to building a SCEM for that setting. On the other hand, studying each new setting in the requisite detail is costly in time, money, and effort, and it is methodologically complex. This is why the intervention-centered approaches pin their hopes on the whole-sale export of successful prediction.

Another lesson of the research, one of immediate practical utility, is that there is a middle ground. Often shortcuts are available, in the form of markers and cautions. We often learn markers that identify underlying structures that afford the same SCEM and also learn cautions about their use without understanding the details of those structures. Human constructions come with labels and use guides or have a characteristic look (like a toaster) that indicates what we can expect them to do. So too with many naturally occurring systems. We can sort nasturtium seeds from acorns and we also learn how to treat them so that they generally do what we expect (‘Plant red acorns in full sun’) even though we have no idea what differentiates them ‘inside’ (and often no-one knows what the structure is and why it affords the possibilities it does). These are central to our ability to predict where the same SCEMs are likely to obtain, even though we know neither the full details of the SCEM nor of the structure that affords it.

The good news, also resulting from project researches, is that we can often turn to meat-and-potatoes social science to find reasonably reliable markers. Consider a hypothetical example from political science. Two countries disagree over boundary issues and tensions mount. Is war likely? The ‘theory of the democratic peace’ (roughly: Democracies don’t go to war with democracies) predicts no if they are both democracies. If this marker is reliable, it can be very useful in planning military or international investment policy. There are a variety of accounts of just what structural features are responsible for the democratic peace. But understanding the details of what affords it is not necessary for prediction.
